Can we ask Redfish via an issue or https://redfishforum.com/ ?
webui-vue is specific to OpenBMC, but a BMC GUI isn't unique. A parameter like webui_enabled isn't unique to OpenBMC.

IPMI/SSH/Telnet aren't part of Redfish but are in the spec. 

https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ManagerNetworkProtocol.v1_10_1.json
```
                "IPMI": {
                    "$ref": "#/definitions/Protocol",
                    "description": "The settings for this manager's IPMI-over-LAN protocol support.",
                    "longDescription": "This object shall contain the IPMI over LAN protocol settings for the manager.  The default `Port` property value should be `623` for compatibility with established client implementations."
                },
...
                "Telnet": {
                    "$ref": "#/definitions/Protocol",
                    "description": "The settings for this manager's Telnet protocol support.",
                    "longDescription": "This object shall contain the Telnet protocol settings for this manager.  The default `Port` property value should be `23` for compatibility with established client implementations."
                },
```

> Can we ask Redfish via an issue or https://redfishforum.com/ ?
> webui-vue is specific to OpenBMC, but a BMC GUI isn't unique. A parameter like webui_enabled isn't unique to OpenBMC.

It is though;  Keep in mind, this option only enables/disables webui-vue, it doesn't disable all UI components.

> 
> IPMI/SSH/Telnet aren't part of Redfish but are in the spec. 
> 
> https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ManagerNetworkProtocol.v1_10_1.json
> ```
>                 "IPMI": {
>                     "$ref": "#/definitions/Protocol",
>                     "description": "The settings for this manager's IPMI-over-LAN protocol support.",
>                     "longDescription": "This object shall contain the IPMI over LAN protocol settings for the manager.  The default `Port` property value should be `623` for compatibility with established client implementations."
>                 },
> ...
>                 "Telnet": {
>                     "$ref": "#/definitions/Protocol",
>                     "description": "The settings for this manager's Telnet protocol support.",
>                     "longDescription": "This object shall contain the Telnet protocol settings for this manager.  The default `Port` property value should be `23` for compatibility with established client implementations."
>                 },
> ```

Yes, but they are well defined protocols for a given server/manager.  A "UI" isn't well defined.

I went to go type up the question in the DMTF just for the hell of it, but I'm not really sure how to pose it in a generic way.  "I want to disable webui-vue at runtime" isn't really a good way to start a dmtf conversation.  Given this feature doesn't disable ALL UIs, we'd have to pose it as disabling a part of the UI?  I'm not sure how we'd specify parts in a standard.

> It is though; Keep in mind, this option only enables/disables webui-vue, it doesn't disable all UI components.

Can we do this for all UI components instead?
It's software, we can do whatever we want, but that wasn't the problem I was trying to solve.

Let's talk with Redfish first. I feel that is needed to clear the bar set by 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OEM_SCHEMAS.md#how-do-i-write-an-oem-schema ;)

Right.... but I'm not sure how to type it up so it doesn't sound insane:
"I want to disable OEM specific pieces of the UI at runtime" is where I started with.  "I want to disable the entire webui" might be reasonable, but that's not what this patch is doing, nor what I intended.  I guess maybe I could start with that?

FWIW, there's a pretty major update to OEM_SCHEMAS.md that I'm about to propose.  Things like

"In the current implementation, OEM schemas for all namespaces are shipped on all systems."
Are no longer true as of the last set of refactoring.  There's documentation on how to create json schemas, and all the compile-time static generation has been moved to runtime, which means that OEM schemas won't be a bear to maintain anymore, and if a system doesn't like them, they can just shut that feature off.
I would like to see Redfish discuss here first.
Should this say "webui-vue? Since this is specific to webui-vue?
done.
Why would that user/company just not include webui-vue in the image?
Because they might produce a BMC that gets used by multiple other people/companies.  The same reason most of our other authentication parameters are selectable at runtime.
